information_requirement: Is the adversary spoofing reporting messages to hide the true state of the industrial process? (PIR)

evidence.description: Reporting messages from a specific field device (e.g., RTU, PLC) exhibit non-sequential or duplicate sequence numbers, or timestamps that are illogical or deviate from the established reporting interval, suggesting message injection or replay.
evidence.nai: Network segments connecting Level 1 (Basic Control) and Level 2 (Supervisory Control) devices.
evidence.action: For each unique device communicating via an ICS protocol (e.g., DNP3), extract and track message sequence numbers and timestamps from protocol-specific Zeek logs. Establish a baseline for the expected reporting frequency and inter-arrival time. Alert on any instance of a duplicate or out-of-order sequence number, or if the time difference (jitter) between consecutive messages from the same device deviates more than 3 standard deviations from its historical baseline.

evidence.description: The telemetry data within a reporting message (e.g., valve status, pressure reading) is inconsistent with data from a separate, trusted data source, such as a physics-based anomaly detection system or a redundant sensor.
evidence.nai: Control system servers (e.g., SCADA Server, Historian) and HMI workstations.
evidence.action: Correlate telemetry data from primary reporting channels (e.g., values in Zeek dnp3.log) with alerts from out-of-band or physics-based anomaly detection systems (logged as Windows Application Event ID 1000). Create a rule that triggers an investigation when a critical process alert is logged by the secondary system but the primary reporting message shows a normal state for the same asset within the same time window.

evidence.description: A reporting message, purportedly from a known field device, originates from an unexpected IP address or exhibits network characteristics (e.g., payload size, TTL value) that are anomalous for that device.
evidence.nai: The OT network backbone and ingress/egress points to the IT network.
evidence.action: Using Zeek conn.log, create a state table mapping known ICS device IP addresses to their typical communication patterns (protocols, ports, average payload size). Alert when a message claims to be from a known device IP but originates from a new network segment or when the payload size of a reporting message deviates significantly (e.g., outside the 5th-95th percentile range) from its historical baseline for that message type.
